title: How many people will have been fully vaccinated against COVID-19 in the US as of 31 May 2021, according to the CDC?
preds: Catching up with my failure to decrement daily! Bin D will only be achieved if the CDC makes major revisions to its late May data between now and the question's resolution on 14 June. I'm allowing a 10% chance for that to happen.

As of May 24, 132.5 million total and 7-day average has plummeted to 792k per day. 7 remaining days x 792k per day = 5.6 million. As of May 31, would have 138.12 million PER STRAIGHT LINE PROJECTION. Usingthe simple calculation above, this total has dropped continuously since the first forecast and is getting closer and close to the line between bins C and D.

130.5M as of 5/21 with 10 days left. On a "peak" day we had 938,000 people vaccinated with 7-day average being about 8% lower than the required 950,000 to hit 140M by 5/31. There's really not a chance we hit it.

My rationale for updating so harshly was (besides prodding to pay attention) a review of all the 10 million vaccine jumps in the past. if you look at the cdc graph that serves as a resolution criteria, the number of days per 10m has been increasing, that ...coupled with the  willingness saturation leads me to think that we will not be able to get over 140 m in the next few days

As of May 21, 130.5 million total and 7-day average has plummeted to 874k per day. 10 remaining days x 874k per day = 8.74 million. As of May 31, would have 139.24 million PER STRAIGHT LINE PROJECTION. Usingthe simple calculation above, this total has dropped continuously since the first forecast and is getting closer and close to the line between bins C and D. This will be a squeaker.

On reconsideration of today's forecast and review of good commentary by the handful of others providing rationales for their updates, I think it's time to move more aggressively toward Bin D given the limited remaining time.

Continuing my countdown to 0% on Bin D. It's still possible that late revisions by the CDC will get the end-of-May numbers over the 140M line, but that's decreasingly likely as the light-blue figures representing what the CDC perceives to be relatively solid numbers continue to be below 1M daily.
The daily grwoth is leveling off, so it probably won't hit the 140M

131.9m plus 1.5m backlog = 133.4m
5 reporting days to go
Threshold for 140m = 6.6m or over 1m per day
Current rate 900k per day and dropping.   Could be close but still unlikely to get to 140m.

Average of 0.95M/day added in the past week through May 25. This number has fallen from 1.47M over the past 3 weeks or so. 6 more days left in forecast (after May 25) + 3 for back reporting. 131.1M (total as of 5/25) + 0.95M/day * 9 days = 139.6M. So, even if the rate at which people are added doesn't continue to decline, we'll be under 140M. But we can expect the decline to continue through May 31; second doses for age 12 to 15 don't start until June. Moreover, it's reasonable to expect that fewer people will be vaccinated over the Memorial Day weekend. (And, there's no chance the numbers will be <130M.)
Afternoon update: An average of 0.91M/day were added in the past week through May 26. Update 5/27: Today's number is 132.8M, with 0.89M/day added in the past week. Forecast total <= 132.8M + 7 * 0.89M = 139M.
Update 5/28: 0.7M added since yesterday. Total now at 133.5M, with 6 forecast days (inc. 3 for back reporting) to go.

As of May 20, 129.4 million total and 7-day average has plummeted to 908k per day. 11 remaining days x 908k per day = 9.99 million. As of May 31, would have 139.4 million PER STRAIGHT LINE PROJECTION. Usingthe simple calculation above, this total has dropped continuously since the first forecast and is getting closer and close to the line between bins C and D. This will be a squeaker.

Continuing my move to Bin C as each day passes below the 1M daily level. Incremental daily shifts will accelerate once reporting for the past weekend solidifies (assuming the retrospective daily average stays below 1M).

I am finding the reporting on this less than reliable/ consistent. There is no way we are having the same amount of vaccines for multiple days in a row. "If" they are correct, then we will barely hit 131,000,000 by resolution date.

Average of 1.0M/day added in the past week (through May 23). As of 4 days ago, 1.11M/day had been added in past week. 1.47M/day in the previous week. 8 more days left in forecast (after May 23) + 3 for back reporting. 130.0M on 5/23 + 1.0M*11 = 141.0M. The number of people receiving a second dose continues to decline and probably won't go up at all until teenagers start receiving their second doses. All we need to see is the average number added/day to fall under 0.91M for the next 11 days for the final number to fall under 140M. That seems extremely likely, especially with the Memorial Day weekend coming up. I think it's very likely that far fewer people will get vaccinated over the Memorial Day weekend.

130M bin is approaching escape velocity. However, even though the tendency to fall is greater, there is still more room for a fall to still arrive at the 130 bin. It only takes an unexpected leveling off to leap this into the 140 bin.

Shifting more to Bin C (fewer than 140M) largely in response to good links from @Chrisp re continuing woes for the 1-shot J&J vaccine. New contamination reports re the Baltimore facility will only enhance the already formidable reluctance of Americans to get this vaccine. Without a viable one-shot option, I have a hard time seeing the average daily rate of new fully vaccinated people getting back over 1M for the remainder of May, which is what we need to see to get into Bin D. I'm still watching for the CDC updates of the numbers for this past weekend, though. Strong updates could persuade me to move some probability back into Bin D.
The rate is slowing, but I want to see the weekend numbers, especially for children before I begin to really change my thinking.
current daily trends make it more likely we will end May under 140k.
Updating based on 5/23/21 numbers from https://ourworldindata.org/covid-vaccinations?country=USA -- reaching 130M but seeing slight decrease in average number of fully vaccinated per day.

As of May 18, 127.44 million total and growing by 987k million per day, per 7-day average. 13 remaining days x 987k per day = 12.83 million. As of May 31, would have 140.27 million PER STRAIGHT LINE PROJECTION. Usingthe simple calculation above, this total has dropped continuously since the first forecast and is getting closer and close to the line between bins C and D. This will be a squeaker.
129,066,466 as of 22 May. We need a daily rate of 1.215 mln from now on to get to 140 mln. The graph doesn't seem to suggest that rate.

As of May 17, 126.32 million total and growing by 1.023 million per day, per 7-day average. 14 remaining days x 1.023 million per day = 14.322 million. As of May 31, would have 140.64 million PER STRAIGHT LINE PROJECTION.

Slight increase because of crowd but watching out because there's a rise in first dose counts. But I don't think correlation is too strong here based on the graph. Have to give it one or two more days to see whether or not there is a continued decline. Unwise to go higher until this is observed.

As of May 16, 125.35 million total and growing by 1.043 million per day, per 7-day average. 14 remaining days x 1.043 million per day = 14.6 million. As of May 31, would have 139.9 million PER STRAIGHT LINE PROJECTION. Just two days ago that same math yielded 141.4 million. Will we see 14.65 million new fully-vaccinated by May 31? That requires we average 1.05 million new cases per day, which is roughly the same as the current 7-day average, which itself may be stabilizing.
Rate is down, and holiday weekend approaching.

Reversing my forecast substantially to 60/40 between bins C and D because the 7-day moving daily average of new fully vaccinated people has dropped more precipitously than I had expected. It's already down close to 1M per day, indicating that the new incentives and initiatives to make it easier for people to get vaccinated are not overcoming the barriers to converting those with a first dose into fully vaccinated individuals. I expect that daily average of new fully vaccinated individuals to begin rising again as the 12-15 year-old group starts to hit full vaccination, but that uptick will be too little, too late to make a meaningful difference to the May numbers.  Current cumulative total as of 20 May on CDC site is just under 127M. I assume some underreporting there, but even if the eventual corrected figure for the 20th is around 130M, we have 11 days to go with a probable daily average of new fully vaccinated people below 1M per day. Should be a squeaker. The realization that has tipped me toward Bin C is that there are two Sundays plus the Memorial Day Monday holiday in the remaining 11 days. Sundays are routinely the lowest days for vaccinations, and Mondays tend to be below-average for weekdays even without the holiday factor. I'll be watching closely for any movement in either direction in the 7-day rolling average. Unless that figure stabilizes and even moves up a bit, I plan to increase my weight on Bin C as time goes on.

The actual value, assuming 549K full vaccinations per day, will be 126 Million + 6 Million = 132 Million. If the number continues to decrease, it will be very close to 130 Million, straddling the 120M-130M and 130M-140M buckets.

The lowest point in the 7-day average since February was 1,421,139/day*. The highest point was 11 April, at 3,305,574. It’s been on a downward trend since then. Total is 126,605,169 fully vaccinated, with 11 days to go.
At 3.3mn/day, it would be 162,905,169 (Bin F). No chance of  that. 
At 2mn/day, it would be 148,605,169 (Bin D). 
At today’s 1.6mn/day*, it would be 144,205,169 (Bin D). 
At 1.4mn/day, it would be 142,005,169 (Bin D). 
At 1.2mn/day, it would be 139,805,169 (Bin C—but on the border with Bin D).  *Some of the doses in the daily average will still be first doses as vaccination is now open to younger people. Fellow commenters have pointed to a rate of 1mn-1.13mn-1.2mn/day. Hedging.

Average of 1.11M/day added in past week. 12 more days left in forecast + 3 for back reporting. 125.45M today + 1.11M*15 = 142.2M. But, in the week before, 1.47M/day were added, for a difference of 0.36M/day or 2.52M/week. If this decline continues, we'll see fewer than 140M fully vaccinated and perhaps closer to 138M. All we need to see is the average number added/day to fall under 0.97M for the next 15 days for the final number to fall under 140M. That seems extremely likely.

As of May 14, 123.7 million total and growing by 1.04 million per day, per 7-day average. 176 remaining days x 1.04 million per day = 17.7 million. As of May 31, would have 141.4 million PER STRAIGHT LINE PROJECTION. Just three days ago that same math yielded 144 million.  Will we see 16.3 million new fully-vaccinated by May 31? That requires we average 959k new cases per day, which is 81k lower than the current 7-day average, which itself continues to plummet downward.   Hedging majorly into Bin C....

The average linear rate only needs to drop by approx 3% to fall one bin down, which seems reasonable and I deem the likely scenario. I guess I could be wrong if the new reopenings further pushes people to get vaccinated. However, I think this hypothesis wouldn't make a big difference because when restrictions are in place, that also encourages people to get vaccinated. They cancel each other out. I also factor my last vaccines forecast where I had predicted just under 100M vaccines because the average rate kept telling me under 100M! 100M! no matter how many angles I looked at the problem from. I think it went up because the daily rates were going up ever so slightly. With that same logic, I think the drastic decreasing trend in daily vaccination means that the average rate should be adjusted lower and I think this result will be between 130 and 140 M. So I'll start here. Adjust to 140/150 bin if the daily rate stabilizes or increases. I do recognize some of the best forecasters on this platform higher than the crowd in the 140M bin. I will keep this in mind. I am wondering whether schools closing for summer break will influence rates.

Quick update since my 5/12/20 prediction. Numbers dropping faster than expected and it will be closer than I had previously estimated (and more close to my original thoughts). Total as of 5/12/21 (last full reported data) - 122,304,397
Required per-day average for 130M - 427,534
Remaining per-day average for 140M - 983,090 We're still trending above the required amount for 140M since last week it required 1,044,821 per day. This bodes well for a 140M number, but we had a precipitous drop from the 1.6M daily doses during the week of 5/3 to 1.2M the week of 5/10 is a pretty worrisome trend. Combine that with the fact that people can just lie about being vaccinated and get their lives back to normal and I'm not quite seeing us pull this out. Will update in a week once we see how this data looks because we should be able to get a better read on the drop-off.

124.5m plus 1.5m for backlog reporting = 126m
12days to go.  
140m threshold = 1.1m per day.
Average just above,  but is dropping quite fast.  Will be close.
Oops shouldn’t have swung so hard to over 140m on last forecast
My forecast is close to the line, but >140M.
Wow, reading the forecasting bars is tough!!!

Tiny tweak for passage of time and review of more recent data, as well as other forecasters' comments. I still see Bin D as the overwhelming favorite, but have swapped my 1% upside hedge on Bin E to increase my downside hedge on Bin C up to 3% (formerly 2%). In spite of the declining 7-day moving average daily rate of full vaccinations, the CDC is still reporting that daily rate to be just under 1.3%. The CDC reports that the US is at approximately 123 million fully vaccinated as of 5/16, with 15 days to go. The 123 million for the 16th will bump up a bit once delayed reports come in. Even ignoring those delayed reports, we only need 17 million more fully vaccinated people to hit Bin D. That's an average of roughly 1.13 million per day for the remainder of the month. It's tough to see how the average drops that quickly, especially with new incentive programs for vaccinations (https://theconversation.com/beer-doughnuts-and-a-1-million-lottery-how-vaccine-incentives-and-other-behavioral-tools-can-help-the-us-reach-herd-immunity-160591) and efforts to make getting a vaccine more convenient (e.g., https://www.expressnews.com/news/local/article/Officials-want-to-make-it-easier-for-you-to-get-16181404.php). These programs are especially important for getting second doses into the arms of the roughly 34 million people who already have taken a first dose but have yet to complete the program. They already showed willingness to be vaccinated; we simply have to make it worth their while to take the time out for dose 2. See also https://www.vox.com/2021/5/5/22419281/covid-19-vaccines-herd-immunity-hesitancy-anti-vaxxers. If I'm slightly off on timing (don't think so, but acknowledge the possibility), I see a silver lining: June should be a great month as eager 12-15-year-olds start getting fully vaccinated for summer camps, schools, etc.!

Into the fray, noting in the CDC data I just reviewed that there must be a reporting glitch as there has been no increase (0) in the last day or so, but I know a few people  who had shot 2 over the weekend. Stay frosty my friends!

As of May 11, 120 million total and growing by 1.2 million per day, per 7-day average. 20 remaining days x 1.2 million per day = 24 million. As of May 31, would have 144 million PER STRAIGHT LINE PROJECTION. But 7-day average has been moving lower steadily since April 11. 20 days ago, 7-day average was growing by 1.45 million per day -- 17% drop over two weeks. Assuming same, we'd end up at just under a million new fully-vaccinated people per day by end of the month. EVEN AT THAT RATE, we'd still end up in Bin D. Now considering exogenous events...resumption of J&J inoculations, changes to vaccine hesitancy, etc.

Current pacing suggest that achieving 140m by end of May as highest probability - we stand at 121m today (may 17). In April there were almost 25m vaccinated in the back half of the month. Vax rates are slowing so May perhaps won't yield the same but reaching 130 looks clearly in sight
Assuming vacc Rate of 1m per day
Does anyone have figures for how reporting for individual days updates over time?  At what point does data for an individual day remain stable? Probably should drop some in the under 30 bucket too

As of May 12th, the number of fully vaccinated people in the US is at 119M with 331M receiving at least one dose (https://ourworldindata.org/covid-vaccinations?country=USA). The average daily rate is 2.09M vaccines—rolling 7-day average, single dose, and may not equal the total number of people vaccinated, depending on the specific dose regime. (https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/daily-covid-19-vaccination-doses). The average daily rate of new individuals fully vaccinated individuals is 1.345 from April 25-May 12 (https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/people-fully-vaccinated-covid?tab=chart&country=~USA). Anyone vaccinated with their first Moderna or Pfizer vaccine from here on out would not add to the total of fully vaccinated people. If you use the average daily rate listed above, the US should reach 143M on May 31. We will see if the new CDC guidelines lead to an uptick in vaccinations or not, but I’m not anticipating a significant upswing, and have chosen my predicted outcomes accordingly.
at the current 7d average, we are on pace for about 145m fully vaccinated, but we are still seeing a general downward trend in the # of fully vaccinated.

119m plus 1.5m backlog = 120.5m
17 days to go
19.5m to get to 140m which is 1.15m per day
Average is still 1.3m so most likely to get beyond 140m.

Someone thankfully pointed out how much the data can shift with the estimated information because my last estimate showed a 1,282,773 7-day average on 5/1. That number has been updated to 1,344,713. Bringing in the basics of my last analysis and accounting for a better understanding of the current data, we are well on track for squeezing past 140,000,000 but not making it to 150,000,000. Using 5/6/21 as the last validated data point, we have 113,879,462 people vaccinated with 25 days of reporting left. This leads to required averages being:
130M -    644,821
140M - 1,044,821
150M - 1,444,821 I don't think any of us are expecting a spike, let alone one sustained enough to break that 150M mark. We're trending around 1.3M doses per day and that means we are around 24% higher than we need to be for the average. If the current trend holds, we would need to see numbers for the last 12 days of May approaching 700,000 people per day and I just don't see that happening. That would require almost halving the current numbers in a very short time span. Updating my last estimates to reflect my new understanding of the data - thanks @Eolienne - we're basically on track and can almost not miss 140,000,000. Probably ending up around 143,000,000 (estimate not based on any actual trend analysis, just a quick understanding of the numbers). It's high enough that I'm not really very worried about being wrong.

116.6m plus 2m for backlog = 118.6m
Threshold for 140m in 19 days needs 21.4m @1.12m per day
Current rate still 1.3m.

CDC data show that nearly 114M people were fully vaccinated as of 6 May, the last day of this forecast for which they do not shade the data as being likely to be revised. As of the same date, a little over 152M had received at least one dose. This figure, plus any one-dose J&J vaccinations occurring through the remainder of May, represents something close to the theoretical maximum of people who could be fully vaccinated by the end of the month, given the minimum three-week lag between 1st & 2nd doses for Pfizer & Moderna. With the J&J vaccine just coming off the recommended pause and the obvious hesitancy of people to resume taking that vaccine, it seems nearly impossible for the # of fully vaccinated to exceed 160M at the end of May. My initial assumption is that the average daily rate of fully vaccinated individuals for the 25 days after May 6th will be between 1 and 1.4M. The 7-day rolling average of daily new "fully vaccinated individuals" as of May 6th was a little over 1.3M; however, the trend was somewhat downward. That trend should have been based almost entirely on new Pfizer & Moderna fully vaccinated individuals given the J&J pause. My base case is that the resumption of J&J vaccinations will be roughly enough to offset the downward trend for 2nd doses of Pfizer & J&J, making the 140-150M bin overwhelmingly the most likely outcome. I'll now review the crowd data to see whether I want to adjust this initial forecast. After that, I'll be watching the trend data closely over the next week to refine my estimate of the average daily number of new fully vaccinated individuals. NOTE: The new recommended approval of the Pfizer vaccine for 12-15 year olds is not reflected in any of these data; however, there is no realistic opportunity for anyone in this age group to become fully vaccinated before the end of May (2 shots).

114.3m today plus 2m for backlog reporting = 116.3m
21 days to go
Threshold 
130m = 650k per day
140m = 1.12m per day As per last forecast, average is still over 1.3m per day which is making the average needed for 140m lower every day.
Average has stabilised, but expect to drop a little in next few days as last fully reported day is lower than equivalent last week.  But not by much and has to drop 200k per day to get below threshold for 140m.   Upping forecast slightly for 140m

Based on the 7-day average of number of people added to this category per day falling by 0.16M/day/week from 2 weeks ago to 1 week ago and extending this trend downward, we could end up almost exactly at 140.0M, too close to call. I should probably weight the lower category more than I am.

110.8m.  Add 2m for backlog reporting = 112.8m
23 days to go
130m = 750k per day
140m = 1.18m per day. Current rate seems to be steadying around 1.3m which would get us back over the 140m so showing this in my forecast.  As the rate has steadied above the 1.18m threshold for 140m every day we have higher than that rate will make the threshold for subsequent days, meaning it’s more and more likely to get past 140m unless another dramatic decrease in 2nd doses happens.

Good assessment by @Skyreichel here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1273977 Although, I am more bullish on the vaccination rates in May staying steady or not tapering off so fast. I believe Pfizer has already been approved for 16-18 yo and 12-15 is imminent: https://eu.usatoday.com/story/news/health/2021/05/03/food-and-drug-administration-likely-authorize-pfizer-biontech-covid-19-vaccine-adolescents-within-ne/4931464001/ However, given the timing, relatively few of these teens will be fully vaxed before EOM.

Updating my numbers because I definitely ignored the fact that it has to be a daily average across the time period. We will probably see numbers below the 785,000 threshold to miss 130M vaccinated people, but the average across this time period is much more likely to be above that. Had it poorly weighted in my last forecast.

We have 25 days left, plus the updates on the most recent data. Current considerations are number of people with first dose already because we only have time for more Pfizer 2-dose vaccinations and the J&J single-dose fully vaccinated. We must also consider the number of people who are vaccine hesitant or will refuse a vaccine because this decreases your ability to get fully vaccinated people when these appointments are going unfilled. I'll be using the current 5/4/21 number at 108,780,169 as a reasonable starting point so 27 days remaining gives us averages of:
415,555 per day average for 120M
785,925 per day for 130M
1,156,296 per day for 140M
1,526,666 per day for 150M I'll stop there because the current 7-day moving average on the CDC's website is at 1,318,000 with little indication that it will move back toward the peak, so in my opinion 150,000,000 or more is definitely out as a possibility. Clearly we should also hit the 120M mark at a minimum because that should happen in the next 10 days at current pace. So we are down to only two threshold questions - will we hit 130M and will we hit 140M? The answer depends on how sharply numbers fall - as fewer people can be vaccinated we have a natural lengthening of time between vaccinations because people's schedules interfere and they feel it is less urgent to get vaccinated since others already are vaccinated. This is fighting against the potential boost from the J&J single-jab vaccine and the government distributing the vaccine to local pharmacies since people trust those more than the hospitals. I'm pretty skeptical Americans actually know what is best for themselves - especially with all the misinformation surrounding COVID (we're still losing over 700 people per day). Looking at the 1,282,773 7-day average from 5/1/21 I have very little faith we will maintain that number above 1,156,296 for the remainder of this month. I'll give it a nod just in case some miracle happens, but I'm much more confident in the lower numbers but not too low.

Following on from yesterday, I think having read up on why vaccinations are dropping (links in comment on the one or more dose question) the rate will still keep dropping, but not as fast as 1st doses.  As 1.3m is the threshold for 140m and this is the current rate, which is going to drop, then makes it less likely to get to 140m.  But has to drop a long way to get to 130m.  Moving forecast more to this 130-140m range.
Expect the rate to slow down,  as the Summer weather takes the wind out of the virus,  and the media moves on to Riot season.

@Ryan-Beck makes the astute observation that people who get one dose of vaccine usually end up getting their second dose within a month. (It was a little under a month in March, but almost exactly 30 days right now.) I also agree with him that the J&J vaccine isn't moving much, and that its effects are likely to be pretty negligible on the forecast total. I include 3 days for back reporting. So, I'm looking to forecast the total reported on June 3. So, if I allow 30 days for people to get a second shot, then the number of people who have had at at least one dose on May 4 (today), 148.6M, should be about the number of people who are fully vaccinated on June 3. By then, though, it might take 31 or 32 days for the same number of people who have had at least one shot to get a second. So this should be a rough upper limit. Looking at it from another angle: 9.5M people added to the total in the past week, or 1.36M/day. If we continue to add 1.36M/day for the next 29 days, we'd get to 107.3M (total today) + 39.4M = 146.7M. I would think this would be an upper limit, as vaccination slows down. 146.7M and 148.6M are thankfully in the higher middle region of the 140M to 150M forecast bin, and I'll be going largely with that one, with a little weight on the lower bin in case a slightly larger fraction of the current population, which is overall less interested in getting vaccinated, decides not to get a second dose. That would require going down to adding an average of 1.13M people/day, which seems very unlikely to me. Also, I'm trying to restrain myself from making 100% forecasts in the beginning, even if I'm 100% certain... at that moment, lol. Update 5/8: 112.6M reported fully vaccinated as of today. 103.4M as of May 1. 9.2M added in 1 week, or 1.31M/day. (93.1M as of Apr 24; 10.3M added that week, or 1.47M/day.) 31 days left in forecast period (allowing 3 days for back reporting). Doses administered are falling every week (by 0.16M/day/week from 2 weeks ago to 1 week ago), so total might be something like 112.6M + 7 * (1.15M + 0.99M + 0.83M + 0.67M) + 3 * .65 = 140.0M. I'll give a little more weight to the lower category.

107.3m today.
25 days to go.
Thresholds:
120m = 500k per day
130m = 900k per day
140m = 1,3m per day
150m = 1,7m per day. Current rate = 1.3m per day.  Dropping, but not clear if temporary or not. Range most likely 135m to 145m.  Going 50/50 to start.

147 million first doses currently. After the 21 to 28 day window that should be the number of people who have their second dose, plus some delay. That held up pretty well last month too. So I'm centering in the 140s with some chance it hits lower or higher. J&J vaccinations have become basically negligible now unfortunately, so I'm not putting much weight on the possibility of J&J vaccinations boosting the fully vaccinated numbers higher.
